2025-05-04 00:34:57,481 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Monetary Authority of Singapore\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: mti’s advance estimates show that the singapore economy expanded by 1.0% on a quarter-on-quarter seasonally-adjusted basis in q3 2023, up from 0.1% in q2.\n                "}]

policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at the same time, inflationary pressures are likely to pick up, driven by rising global commodity prices as well as some domestic cost factors.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the decline was concentrated in the manufacturing sector, reflecting sluggish external conditions.\n                "}]

policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: gdp growth is estimated to have fallen to 1.8% (year-on-year) in h1 2001, from 10.7% in h2 2000, led by a sharp slowdown in manufacturing and weakening domestic demand.\n                "}]

lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: mas core inflation and cpi-all items inflation are expected to ease further before rising towards the end of the year and into 2016, as global oil prices pick up and the effects of the reduction in healthcare costs fade.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: mas core inflation is likely to be stable in the near term.\n                "}]

\\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: as existing vaccines have been effective in limiting severe illness from the dominant covid-19 variant, and as inoculation rates rise globally, consumption activity should pick up while supply constraints ease.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that consumption activity will pick up and supply constraints will ease, implying a more optimistic economic outlook, which is conducive to a dovish monetary policy stance."
}

policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the 2015 growth forecast for the singapore economy remains at 2–4%.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the global it industry is expected to grow at about the same rate as in 2005, providing support not only to the domestic electronics industry, but also the entrepot trade and the hub-related transport services industries.\n                "}]

policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the trade-weighted s$ has generally been appreciating over the past year in line with the policy stance, and is now within the upper-half of the policy band.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: a sharp escalation in geopolitical and trade conflicts could exert sizeable drags on global and domestic investment and trade.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that geopolitical and trade conflicts could negatively impact investment and trade, implying a potential need for accommodative monetary policy to support the economy."
}

secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: singapore's three-month s$ interbank rate eased from 0.81% at end-2002 to 0.75% at end-mar and 0.63% at end-jun, in line with the decline in global interest rates and slack liquidity conditions in the domestic money market.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker recovery is subject to significant uncertainty.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: meanwhile, the domestic-oriented sectors remained weak, with many affected by the tighter measures imposed in response to the increase in covid-19 infections.\n                "}]

Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: this policy stance, which has been in place since april 2004, was assessed to be appropriate for containing any rise in inflationary pressures amidst higher global inflation and domestic costs.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: reflecting the recovery in coe premiums, cpi-all items inflation rose to 1.9% in july-august, from 1.6% in q2 2013.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence simply reports on inflation data without expressing a stance or suggesting any monetary policy action."

Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: while some slowdown is expected, overall economic conditions in the region should stay firm.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n
