2025-05-04 00:35:57,498 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Monetary Authority of Singapore\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: core inflation should end the year around 2%, and average between 2.5%–3.0% for 2024 as a whole, down from 4.2% in 2023.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are expected to decrease, creating room for expansionary monetary policy."
}

Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the singapore economy is expected to strengthen over 2024, with growth becoming more broad-based.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: global capital expenditure has begun to turn up amid some strengthening in business sentiment, while improving labour market conditions should sustain final demand in the developed economies.\n                "}]

\n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: for 2018, core inflation should come in within the upper half of the 1–2% forecast range.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: excluding the impact of the gst increase in january this year, however, core inflation will be lower compared to 2022.\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The statement suggests that core inflation will be lower, indicating a reduction in inflationary pressures, which creates room for expansionary monetary policy."
}

Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: according to the advance estimates released by the ministry of trade and industry today, the singapore economy expanded by 1.3% on a year-ago basis in q1 2019, following the 1.9% growth in q4 2018.\n                "}]

monetary policy decisions or stances.\n Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: thus, cpi inflation is expected to remain high until the middle of the year, before easing in the second half.\n                "}]

\n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence:              "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: for 2005 as a whole, headline cpi inflation is expected to come in at 0-1%, before rising to 1-2% in 2006.\n                "}]

"justification": "The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are expected to remain low, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy."

of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: conditions in the it industry are likely to remain sluggish till later in the year, although the non-electronics clusters are expected to maintain healthy growth.\n                "}]

policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in 2023, the economy is forecast to grow at a pace that is below trend, which could cause the current mildly positive output gap to reverse.\n                "}]

following the rapid economic growth in h2 2000 and significant tightening in the labour market, the economy's output gap has narrowed and is estimated to have turned slightly positive by the end of last year.\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nevertheless, it will take time for the expansion to gather momentum and become more broad-based, before a significant improvement in the labour market can be seen.\n                "}]

no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: on a quarter-on-quarter seasonally adjusted annualised basis, gdp contracted by 5.8% in q1 2005.\n                "}]

involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: advance estimates released by the ministry of trade and industry today indicated that the singapore economy expanded by 2.0% on a quarter-on-quarter seasonally-adjusted basis in q1 2021, moderating from the 3.8% growth in q4 2020.\n                "}]
